Yes!
@pydanny so for each action, I'd do something like : login user -> add permission -> test action for success -> remove permission -> test action for failure ?

@pydanny question about tests - do the settings set in one test affect those in another? I noticed that you set RESTRICT_PACKAGE_EDITORS to True at the start of the test, but then set it back to False at the end. I assumed tests were independent of each other, but maybe this isn't the case?
back from a long outing with family; I was working on some JS improvements. Not really a big refactor yet, but the search should work better.
I always assume that the bleeding happens and write my code to deal with it.

@pydanny Also I was wondering what the best practice was for writing these sort of true/false tests? Part of me thinks that because we are looking for Unit tests, we'd want to separate the success/fail into two parts. But on the other hand, it seems like a large part of the code is repeated, so I feel like you could do something like : login user -> set restriction -> test fail -> add user permission -> test success -> unset restriction -> test success
Would splitting them be best, though, ultimately? I feel like since individual asserts are clearly enumerated, it would be simple to tell, even in the slightly larger test, which part fails, if any
Sweet
So @grobolom things sometimes bleed. I'm not sure about the details

This is making my checklist for launching Python Packages really small!
If you want to keep the pull requests seperate, create a branch for each one that is descriptive of what is going on
the advantage of one pull, is that it makes it easier too keep going without waiting for you to merge the first
if one is based on the other
Plus, from a resume standpoint it demonstrates clearly that you know your stuff. Both in git controls and also in how you cleanup code.
Just saying...
he is talking about refactoring the tests themselves....
Feature branches are a pretty standard way of keeping pull requests separate in open source projects.
